title: 108_s1235
content: The "Winning the Peace Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title. The findings section is included in the Act. Congress finds that failed states can harbor various transnational threats, including terrorist networks and organized crime, posing a risk to US security and its allies. The inability of failed states to provide basic services can lead to humanitarian emergencies. It is in the interest of the US and the international community to resolve conflicts and humanitarian crises in failed states. Post-conflict reconstruction efforts have been undertaken in countries like Iraq, Bosnia, Kosovo, Somalia, Haiti, Rwanda, East Timor, and Afghanistan. The challenge of assisting failed states emerging from violent conflict is complex and long-term, with a high risk of relapse into violence within 5 years. A 2003 report highlighted the need for updated strategies by the US and international community to address the challenges posed by failed states. The international community needs to develop a strategy and enhance capacity for post-conflict reconstruction efforts. The international community needs to develop a strategy and enhance capacity for post-conflict reconstruction efforts. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, while "Director" means a Director of Reconstruction designated by the President. "Reconstruction services" involve activities related to rebuilding, reforming, or establishing infrastructure in conflict-affected countries, including security, public safety, disarmament, justice, and rule of law development. The curr_chunk focuses on rebuilding and stabilizing conflict-affected countries through various means such as judicial, correctional, and governance reforms, supporting human rights, justice for war criminals, national reconciliation, property rights clarification, economic development, social well-being, and infrastructure construction. The curr_chunk discusses developing national economic institutions, such as a banking system, and encouraging wise stewardship of natural resources for the benefit of the citizens of a country. SEC. 4. DIRECTOR OF RECONSTRUCTION POSITIONS. The President is authorized to designate a civilian as the Director of Reconstruction for countries or regions where US Armed Forces have been in armed conflict or where reconstruction services will be provided. The President can provide reconstruction services for designated countries or regions, with the Director overseeing and coordinating all related activities of the US Government. The Director of Reconstruction oversees and coordinates post-conflict reconstruction programs in designated countries or regions, coordinating with other entities to avoid duplication of services and utilize expertise available. The Secretary of State can establish a permanent office to provide support services to each Director designated. The Secretary of State can establish a permanent office to provide administrative support to each Director designated. The Administrator is authorized to establish an Office of International Emergency Management within the United States Agency for International Development. The purposes of this office include developing a database of reconstruction experts and mobilizing them to provide services in countries or regions in need. Additionally, individuals or entities with expertise may include government employees, former Peace Corps volunteers, or civilians in affected areas. The Sense of Congress is to establish an Integrated Security Support Component within NATO to train and equip selected units for security in countries needing reconstruction. The President can commit US personnel to participate in this Component with Congress consultation. The Integrated Security Support Component within NATO aims to train and equip units for security in countries requiring reconstruction. US personnel participating in this Component should be capable of providing security for civilians, serving as a police force, and executing security tasks such as controlling belligerent groups, apprehending targeted individuals, and supporting police investigations. SEC. 7. TRAINING CENTER FOR POST-CONFLICT RECONSTRUCTION OPERATIONS. The Secretary of State will establish an interagency Training Center for Post-Conflict Reconstruction Operations to train personnel, develop experts, provide training, create deployable packages, and conduct reviews to improve reconstruction services. Developing training and education programs for individuals providing reconstruction services is essential as part of the interagency Training Center for Post-Conflict Reconstruction Operations. The President must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment detailing the planned actions to implement its provisions.
